Award.AwardTitle: CI-EN: Trust-Hub: Development of Benchmarks, Metrics, and Validation Platforms for Hardware Security, and a Web-based Dissemination Portal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growing hardware security community is faced with an immediate need to develop effective tools and benchmarks. The purpose of this project is to lead a community-wide movement toward stronger assurances in our integrated circuits, computational platforms, and electronics supply chain. Based on the proven effectiveness of information sharing in many communities including crypto and computer-aided design, the PIs plan a significant enhancement and increase in scope of Trust-Hub, a central web-based repository for benchmarks, hardware authentication platforms, evaluation software, source codes, tools, and much more in the area of hardware security and trust.

The intellectual merits of this project include development of (i) procedures to dynamically generate trust benchmarks with hard-to-detect Trojan instances, (ii) hardware platforms for security validation, (iii) a suite of security metrics, (iv) a suite of ready to apply attacks, and (viii) comprehensive hardware/software validation test suites and data. The results of this project would be of interest to semiconductor companies, US government agencies and university researchers worldwide. Benefits to the society include secure and trustworthy electronics for healthcare, defense, finance, transportation, automotive and other applications. This research will impact the education of students, industry professionals, and government agencies' engineers through courses, online materials, and on- and off-campus seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this community project has been to lead a community-wide movement toward stronger assurances in our ICs, computational platforms, and supply chain. Based on the proven effectiveness of information sharing in many communities including crypto, computer aided design/electronic desgin automation, testing, security etc., we contributed to a significant enhancement and increase in scope of Trust-Hub, a central web-based repository for technical papers, benchmarks, platforms, evaluation software, source codes, tools, and much more in the area of hardware security and trust. (https://www.trust-hub.org)

Specifically, we have contributed to platforms for hardware security research, in particular those that have to do with chips with a wireless interface, and we have made several contributions to FPGA-based as well as simulation/emulation-based methods for hardware security. We have published several research papers that greatly enhance the state-of-the-art in HW and embedded systems security, and made open-source codes available in GitHub and Trust-Hub repositories for other researchers and practitioners to use. Data and benchmarks are made available to ease comparison among various methods and lead the hardware security community towards a more coherent and consistent progress.

This research has had impact on the education of students, in particular women and minoritiers, industry professionals, and government agencies engineers through courses, online materials, and on- and off-campus seminars. By integrating the results of this project into existing courses and by offering new undergraduate/graduate courses, the PI and others using the material will continue to impart cutting-edge engineering knowledge to students at its home institute and beyond, and improve their hardware design and security validation skills.

 

Processors and hardware platforms are omnipresent in contemporary lives. The results of this project significantly improve safety and security of various computing platforms that form the backbone of our society, as well as software and data than run on these platforms. They also contribute to retaining the competitive advantage of true innovators by devising novel hardware IP protection methodologies.

The results of this project has a significant impact on the envisioned 50B IoT industry where security is one of the major roadblocks to universal application of this technology in homes, offices, industry, government and businesses which would impact society in myriads of ways.
